description.en: The course examines both legal and political aspects of the United Nations. The introductory lectures are devoted to the idea and history behind the establishment of the organisation. Then, in the seminars, the issues like the nature, relevance and legal status of the charter, structure, membership, financing, conflict prevention and peace operations, peace-building and sanctions, development and self-determination, human rights and humanitarian assistance, immunity and responsibility as well as reform proposals are discussed.
description.et: Kursus käsitleb Ühinenud Rahvaste Organisatsiooni nii õiguslikke kui ka poliitilisi aspekte. Sissejuhatavad loengud on pühendatud organisatsiooni loomise mõttele ja ajaloole. Seejärel arutatakse seminarides selliseid teemasid nagu harta olemus, relevantsus ja õiguslik olemus, struktuur, liikmelisus, finantseerimine, konflikti ennetamine ja rahuoperatsioonid, rahuloomine ja sanktsioonid, areng ja enesemääramine, inimõigused ja humanitaarabi, immuniteet ja vastutus ning reformide ettepanekud.

objectives.en: To provide a comprehensive understanding of the history, purposes, structure, practice and challenges of the United Nations with an emphasis on legal aspects
objectives.et: Anda mitmekülgne arusaam Ühinenud Rahvaste Organisatsiooni ajaloost, eesmärkidest, struktuurist, praktikast ja väljakutsetest, pöörates erilist tähelepanu õiguslikele aspektidele

learning_outcomes.en: The student who has passed the course:
-- Outlines the history of the United Nations and recognises the role of the organisation in world politics
learning_outcomes.et: -- Esitab Ühinenud Rahvaste Organisatsiooni ajaloo olulisemad sammud ja mõistab organisatsiooni rolli maailma poliitikas

learning_outcomes.en: -- Explains the purposes and functioning principles of the organisation
learning_outcomes.et: -- Selgitab organisatsiooni eesmärke ja toimimise põhimõtteid

learning_outcomes.en: -- Describes the structure of the organisation and how the organisation and its specialised agencies are functioning
learning_outcomes.et: -- Kirjeldab organisatsiooni struktuuri ning kuidas organisatsioon ja selle spetsialiseeritud asutused toimivad

learning_outcomes.en: -- Points out the fields where the organisation is active and judges what has been achieved and where the progress is lagging
learning_outcomes.et: -- Toob välja valdkonnad, kus organisatsioon tegutseb, ning hindab, millistes valdkondades on saavutatud edu ja millistes on vajakajäämisi

learning_outcomes.en: -- Identifies political and legal arguments used in discussions and comprehends the decision-making processes in the organisation
learning_outcomes.et: -- Eristab diskussioonis kasutatavaid poliitilisi ja õiguslikke argumente ning mõistab organisatsioonis toimuvaid otsustusprotsesse

independent_work.et:
(1) Independent work with study materials
(2) Writing a research paper
In the research paper, the student analyses critically certain aspect of the United Nations and its activities in the light of international law.
The selected problem should be registered via Moodle no later than on the day of last lecture. The instructor may ask the student to choose another problem if the chosen problem is not suitable or too many students have already chosen the same problem. The paper should be submitted electronically as a Word-file no later than on 4 December at 12:00 (noon) via Moodle. For every started overdue day, the result will be decreased by four points, but papers which are late more than four days are not accepted and the student may not take the exam. The instructor cannot consider papers sent by email.
The paper must include title page, table of content, main body and list of used materials. For references, use footnotes. The length of main text (starting from the introduction and ending with the conclusion, excluding footnotes) should be 2000-2500 words. Shorter papers are not accepted or the result is lowered by the discretion of the instructor.
Independent identification of clear issues and legal problems is very important. Also, the use of different sources and supportive materials. All used sources must be referred to. In case of internet sources, the full address is necessary, not only the main domain (e.g. www.un.org). A paper based on copy-paste method leads to negative results for both the paper and the exam. Plagiarism is not tolerated at the University of Tartu.

description.et:
Criteria
-- Consistency, completeness and correctness of the answers to theoretical questions
-- Creativeness and consistency of the solutions to hypothetical cases
-- Depth of the analysis of problems and applicable norms and principles
-- Association of theory with state and court practice
-- Structure, grammar and formatting
Grades
A: Answers to theoretical questions are remarkable; the examination of hypothetical cases is full, logical and creative; the analysis of legal problems is detailed and innovative; all relevant norms and principles have been used; the references to state and court practice are thoughtful and creative; the form is excellent; overall, the text is a remarkable achievement [91-100 points]
B: Answers to theoretical questions are very good with insignificant mistakes or omissions; the examination of hypothetical cases is purposeful and creative; the analysis of legal problems is very good with insignificant deficiencies; necessary norms and principles have been used; the references to state and court practice support the conclusions; the form is very good; overall, the treatment of the subject is logical and smooth [81-90 points]
C: Answers to theoretical questions are good, but there are mistakes or omissions; the examination of hypothetical cases addresses correctly the central issues; the analysis of legal problems is good with some deficiencies concerning specific issues; key norms and principles have been used; the form is good; overall, the coverage of the subject is logical, but there are some weaknesses from the point of view of the whole [71-80 points]
D: Answers to theoretical questions are fair, but there are several mistakes or omissions; the examination of hypothetical cases is satisfactory, but focuses only on the central aspects; the analysis of legal problems is satisfactory with deficiencies is most aspects; only basic norms and principles have been used; the form is fair; overall, the treatment of the subject is plausible, but insecure [61-70 points]
E: Answers to theoretical questions are poor with significant mistakes or omissions; the examination of hypothetical cases is weak and limited only to the very basic aspects; the analysis of legal problems is shallow with significant deficiencies is most aspects; only some rudimentary norms and principles have been used; overall, the coverage of the subject suffers of superficial treatment, poor knowledge of law and unsound presentation [51-60 points]

grade_preconditions.et:
(1) Participation in seminars (a student may miss two seminars)
If a student did not participate in a seminar, he/she must submit, within a week, a two-page summary of the key points of the topic discussed in the particular seminar. Each late submission of a summary decreases the final points by three points.
(2) Timely submission and positive evaluation of a research paper.

grade_evaluation.et:
(1) Written exam with two questions (60 points)
(2) Research paper (40 points)

debt_elimination.et: In accordance with the Study Regulations and in consultation with the course instructor

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.mandatory_materials:
Books
-- Simon Chesterman, Ian Johnstone & David M. Malone, Law and Practice of the United Nations: Documents and Commentary (2nd edn, New York: Oxford University Press, 2016)
Treaties and Documents
-- Charter of the United Nations (1945)
-- Convention on the Privileges and Immunities of the United Nations (1946)
-- Other treaties and documents mentioned in the book Law and Practice of the United Nations: Documents and Commentary (2nd edn)
